CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1+6-3-a;Violation of Art. 6-1+6-3-b;Violation of Art. 6-1;Pecuniary damage - financial award;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . Mr Pélissier was born in DATE and lives at ORG ; Mr PERSON was born in DATE and lives at GPE . Both are NORP nationals .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON formed a private limited company ( société à responsabilité limitée – Sàrl ) , NORP , whose object was the sale of pleasure craft . PERSON was appointed manager . In DATE NORP started to trade with a public company , ORG , whose object was boat - building . On DATE , NORP became ORG exclusive distributor for the ORG département coast .

Its objects were the development of port infrastructures , harbour building and the sale and outfitting of boats . The share capital was held by PERSON GPE ( CARDINAL shares ) , the applicants ( CARDINAL shares ) , and PERSON ( ORG shares ) . CARDINAL . By agreements made with ORG and another company , ORG , NORP was granted a licence allowing it to launch its boats on the sea front .
CARDINAL . NORP In DATE relations between NORP and ORG started to deteriorate , the former owing the latter MONEY ( ORG ) . ORG then terminated the distribution agreement with ORG .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE PERSON filed for insolvency . On DATE ORG held that the company was insolvent and ordered its judicial reorganisation .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , finding that NORP had debts of QUANTITY , ordered its liquidation under the supervision of the court .

On DATE ORG lodged a complaint with the senior GPE investigating judge against a person or persons unknown for forgery of commercial documents and fraud by the falsification of a balance sheet and its use with a view to obtaining a rescheduling of debt which would never be honoured . On DATE the investigating judge sent instructions to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON , the manager of NORP , was charged by the GPE investigating judge assigned to the case . On DATE an additional charge of negligent and fraudulent bankruptcy was brought against him . On CARDINAL DATE the investigating judge ’s instructions of DATE were carried out . The results revealed in particular the existence of a property holding company ( société civile immobilière ) , ORG , which had been set up by PERSON , Mr PERSON and PERSON wife , in order to acquire land for letting to PERSON .

On DATE Mr and PERSON lodged a complaint against PERSON and any other person having managerial responsibility for NORP , alleging misappropriation and , subsequently , fraud , in connection with the purchase and payment for a boat that was never delivered . On DATE a Mr PERSON lodged a complaint against PERSON for misappropriation and applied to be joined to the proceedings as a civil party claiming damages .

CARDINAL . On DATE , after appearing before the investigating judge on DATE and CARDINAL DATE , the first applicant was charged with the offences set out in the complaint of DATE and with negligent and fraudulent bankruptcy and misappropriation .
CARDINAL . On DATE the second applicant was charged with the same offences .

CARDINAL . After PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE , which reformed insolvency law , came into force , the public prosecutor , considering there to be “ strong evidence of criminal bankruptcy ” , lodged an additional application to have PERSON , PERSON and the applicants charged with that offence under the new law . In so doing , he relied on the provisions relating to criminal bankruptcy and aiding and abetting criminal bankruptcy .

CARDINAL . NORP In a letter of CARDINAL DATE to the investigating judge , the lawyer acting for ORG argued that a charge of aiding and abetting criminal bankruptcy might lie against the applicants . On DATE ORG applied to be joined to the criminal bankruptcy proceedings as a civil party claiming damages .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating judge preferred an additional charge of “ criminal bankruptcy ” against PERSON under sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Law of DATE and ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW . On DATE , DATE and DATE he preferred identical additional charges of “ criminal bankruptcy ” against the first applicant , the second applicant and PERSON respectively .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating judge appointed CARDINAL accounting experts to audit the accounts .
CARDINAL . On DATE they submitted their report to the investigating judge .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating judge made an order transmitting the file to the public prosecutor for submissions ( ordonnance de soit - communiqué ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating judge made a discharge order on the charges of forgery and using forged commercial documents , negligent and fraudulent bankruptcy and fraud ; ultimately , the only charge on which the applicants were committed to stand trial at ORG was that of criminal bankruptcy under LAW DATE . A discharge order was also made in the case of PERSON on the same charges and on the complaint lodged by PERSON and PERSON . He was committed to stand trial at ORG alone ( on certain charges for which he was the sole defendant ) , with PERSON ( on charges relating to the management of ORG ) , and with the applicants . In his order , the investigating judge cited Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Criminal Code and sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Law of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG sentenced PERSON to DATE imprisonment and a fine of ORG CARDINAL for fraudulent bankruptcy , concealment of assets and misappropriation . It acquitted PERSON of the charges against him . Of the civil parties , ORG application to be joined to the criminal bankruptcy proceedings was declared inadmissible and the court noted that PERSON and PERSON had withdrawn their application to be joined as civil parties ; the only person to be awarded compensation was PERSON ( in respect of the misappropriation by PERSON ) .
CARDINAL . In the same judgment , ORG held with regard to the bankruptcy charges against the applicants :
“ It should firstly be noted that under the LAW only de jure or de facto managers , not , as suggested by the prosecution , members , can commit the offence .

Without it being necessary to consider whether the indictment is bad for failure to allege that the members [ the applicants ] were de facto managers , that being an essential element of the offence , it need only be observed that [ the applicants ] have not performed any acts of management , the de jure manager can not be regarded as having been a ‘ replaceable’ , compliant manager and it does not appear that he gave the other CARDINAL the right to sign on his behalf .
Thus , as they can not properly be described as de jure managers , the defendants PERSON and PERSON must be acquitted of these offences . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG appealed against that judgment . The public prosecutor and PERSON did likewise on DATE . On DATE ORG lodged additional submissions with the registry of ORG in which they proposed , in the alternative , recharacterising the acts the applicants were alleged to have committed as “ aiding and abetting ” criminal bankruptcy .

CARDINAL . On DATE , after hearings on DATE and DATE , the Aix - en - ORG held that although the applicants could not be regarded as having been de facto managers of the company , they had nonetheless been informed of the serious difficulties it was in and had “ wilfully performed positive , material acts that had facilitated , aided or abetted PERSON in the concealment of assets to the detriment of NORP ” . It appears from the judgment that the applicants were regarded as appearing before ORG as “ defendants on criminal bankruptcy charges ” .

CARDINAL . ORG consequently held that the applicants were guilty , not of the offences charged , but of the separate offence of aiding and abetting criminal bankruptcy through the concealment of assets . As regards the first applicant in particular , ORG found , inter alia , that he had furnished a false certificate in order to justify the payment of a sum of money in a suspect operation . It referred in its judgment to ORG main submissions requesting the ORG conviction for criminal bankruptcy , but made no mention of the additional submissions lodged on DATE concerning the accusation that they had aided and abetted criminal bankruptcy . There is a dispute as to whether that request was brought to the attention of the applicants ; however , it is common ground that it was mentioned , as an ancillary point , by the civil party at the hearing .

CARDINAL . The Aix - en - Provence Court of Appeal sentenced each of the applicants to a suspended term of CARDINAL months’ imprisonment and to a fine of ORG CARDINAL . While upholding the conviction of PERSON and the partial discharge order made in his favour by ORG , it nonetheless increased the term of imprisonment to DATE , while suspending it , and the fine to ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL . Lastly , ORG upheld PERSON acquittal , the award of damages to PERSON and the declaration that ORG application to be joined as a civil party was inadmissible .

CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE the applicants appealed against that decision to ORG on points of law . In their pleadings they denied the offence and contended on the basis of LAW that ORG decision to convict them of an offence different from that charged had not been the subject of adversarial argument and had infringed the rights of the defence . In addition , the first applicant submitted that when referring to alleged irregularities on his account ORG had relied on allegations that had never been put to him and were incapable of showing that he had aided and abetted criminal bankruptcy .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed the applicants’ appeal on the grounds that :

“ ... the reasons given in the impugned judgment enable ORG to satisfy itself that the court below sufficiently made out , within the limits of its jurisdiction , all the constitutive elements of the actus reus and mens rea
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW provide :

“ The Criminal Court shall be seised of offences within its jurisdiction on the voluntary appearance of the parties , a summons accompanied by a statement of the charges , an immediate summary trial or , lastly , a committal by the investigating judge or judges . ”
“ The case is transferred to ORG to the extent determined in the notice of appeal ... ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW in force at the material time were as follows :
“ Accessories to a serious crime ( crime ) or other major offence ( délit ) shall be liable to the same penalties as the principals , except where statute provides otherwise . ”

“ A person who , by gifts , promises , threats , abuse of authority or power , scheming or contrivance , has incited the commission of a serious crime ( crime ) or other major offence ( délit ) or given instructions for its commission ;
has procured weapons , implements or any other means of assisting in the commission of an offence knowing that such weapons , implements or other means were intended for that purpose ; or

has knowingly aided or abetted the principal or principals in acts preparatory to the commission of the offence or facilitating its commission or in carrying out the offence , shall be guilty of an offence as accessories , without prejudice to the penalties specially imposed by this LAW on persons conspiring to commit or inciting breaches of ORG security , even if the crime intended by those conspiring or inciting is not committed . ”

“ Persons found guilty of criminal bankruptcy shall be liable on conviction to between three months’ and DATE imprisonment and a fine of between FRF CARDINAL and ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL or to either of those penalties .
In addition , an order may be made barring them from exercising the rights referred to in LAW . ”

“ Accessories to criminal bankruptcy shall be liable to the same penalties as those laid down in DATE , even if they are not merchants , craftsmen or farmers and do not directly or indirectly , de facto or de jure , manage a private - law legal entity having an economic activity . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of this law read as follows :
“ The provisions of this LAW are applicable to :
( CARDINAL ) all traders and craftsmen ;
( CARDINAL ) anyone who has directly or indirectly , whether de jure or de facto , managed or liquidated a private - law entity having an economic activity ; and
( CARDINAL ) NORP individuals who are permanent representatives of entities managing entities as defined in subsection CARDINAL above . ”
“ Where judicial reorganisation proceedings are commenced , the persons referred to in section CARDINAL shall be guilty of criminal bankruptcy if they are found to have done any of the following :

( CARDINAL ) with the intention of avoiding or delaying the commencement of judicial reorganisation proceedings , made purchases with a view to resale at less than market value or used ruinous means to procure funding ;
( CARDINAL ) misappropriated or concealed all or part of the debtor ’s assets ;
( CARDINAL ) NORP fraudulently increased the debtor ’s liabilities ; or
( CARDINAL ) held fictitious accounts or caused accounting documents of the undertaking or entity to disappear or failed to keep any accounts . ”
